sentence.text: Concomitant proton pump inhibitors with mycophenolate mofetil and the risk of rejection in kidney transplant recipients.
Recent pharmacokinetic studies have demonstrated that proton pump inhibitors (PPI) reduce exposure of mycophenolic acid
However, the clinical significance of this drug-drug interaction on transplantation outcomes has not been determined
This was a retrospective cohort study in kidney transplant recipients who were prescribed rabbit antithymocyte globulin, calcineurin inhibitor, mycophenolate mofetil, and steroids
We evaluated the impact of PPI use on the 1-year rates of biopsy-proven acute rejection (BPAR)
Two hundred thirteen patients who were prescribed PPI were compared with 384 patients who were on standard acid-suppressive therapy with ranitidine

At 1 year, BPAR type, BPAR grade, patient and graft survival, graft function, and time to BPAR were not associated with PPI exposure
In this retrospective study, PPI use in the first transplant year was associated with an increased risk for BPAR in black patients but not in non-black patients
